headline.main: The Brave, and Now the Few

docs.abstract: Article on drop in number of volunteer firefighters on Long Island that is leaving some communities facing critical shortages; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: ROBERT GALIONE'S lifelong passion is fighting fires. A New York City firefighter for more than 20 years, he joined the Lakeland Fire Department in 1985, serving as a volunteer firefighter and later as commissioner. On top of working nearly 50 hours a week at a Brooklyn rescue company, Mr. Galione, a 44-year-old father of three, spent 30 hours a week at the firehouse in Ronkonkoma. ''I would sit down to eat dinner with my family and at least two or three times a week, the alarm would go off, and by the time I would come back, no one was at the table and my dinner was cold,'' he said. ''You have to hope people in your life understand.''

headline.main: Making Noise a Legal Issue Would Skirt Confrontations

docs.abstract: Susan Bruck Isaacson letter on August 6 responses to Peter Applebome's column on loud, obscene rap music being played by man at gas pump (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: After reading the responses regarding the man with the very loud radio in a gas station (Soapbox, Aug. 6), I thought of the effects on one's health, and specifically one's hearing. If citations were issued for noise pollution as they are for other infractions like littering or smoking in nonsmoking areas, then the need for debating confrontations of any kind and the possible ramifications would be avoided. SUSAN BRUCK ISAACSON Warwick, N.Y.
